New-York Historical Society
Saint Andrew's Society of the State of New York records
Saint Andrew's Society of the State of New York
MS 2997
118 Linear feet
1785-2014 The collection contains records (1785-2014) of the Saint Andrew's Society of the State of New York, a Scottish-American charitable and social organization. The records document the organization's administrative history, membership, charitable efforts, and cultural events. Materials in this collection may be stored offsite. For more information on making arrangements to consult them, please visit www.nyhistory.org/library/visit.
Biographical/Historical Note
The Saint Andrew's Society of the State of New York was founded in 1756 to provide charitable relief and promote social ties within the growing Scottish-American community. It followed the founding of Saint Andrew's Societies in Charleston (1729), Philadelphia (1747), and Savannah (1750), as well as the Scots Society of New-York (1744-1753). In 1775, meetings were suspended due to the Revolutionary War. At that time the Society's membership included both British officers and American revolutionaries. Three members—Philip Lawrence, Lewis Morris, and John Witherspoon—were signers of the Declaration of Independence. In 1784 the Society reorganized and resumed its original mission. There are few records from this early period, however, because in 1835, most documents, including the original constitution signed by the founding members, were lost in a fire.
The Society's membership was initially open only to Scottish men and their sons and grandsons. In 1897, membership was opened to men of any Scottish lineal descent. The membership of the society involved many political, commercial, and cultural leaders. During the Civil War, a number of members served in the 79th New York Volunteer Infantry, nicknamed the Highland Guard. Other prominent members include: Philip Livingston, William Livingston, Robert R. Livingston, Alexander Hamilton, John Loudon McAdam, Washington Irving, Andrew Carnegie, James Gordon Bennett, Alexander Graham Bell, John Lindsay, and Thomas J. Watson Jr.
Scope and Contents Note
The Saint Andrew's Society of the State of New York Records document several significant aspects of Scottish and American history in New York. As a social club that attracted prominent individuals to its leadership and events, and as an aid organization that served Scots in need, the Society produced records that reflect the lives of a wide variety of people within the New York area's Scottish community.
The records contain many types of material, including minutes, financial ledgers, committee records, and ephemera.
The collection is arranged in the following six series:
Series I: Administrative Records
Series II: Charitable Records
Series III: Membership Records
Series IV: Event Records
Series V: The Pibroch
Series VI: Miscellaneous Historical Material
A more detailed description of the contents of each series is included in the container list.
Immediate Source of Acquisition Note
Gift of Saint Andrew's Society of the State of New York, 2015
Use Restrictions
Taking images of documents from the library collections for reference purposes by using hand-held cameras and in accordance with the library's photography guidelines is encouraged. As an alternative, patrons may request up to 20 images per day from staff.
Application to use images from this collection for publication should be made in writing to: Department of Rights and Reproductions, The New-York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West, New York, NY 10024-5194, rightsandrepro@nyhistory.org. Phone: (212) 873-3400 ext. 282.
Copyrights and other proprietary rights may subsist in individuals and entities other than the New-York Historical Society, in which case the patron is responsible for securing permission from those parties. For fuller information about rights and reproductions from N-YHS visit: https://www.nyhistory.org/about/rights-reproductions
Access Restrictions
Materials in this collection may be stored offsite. For more information on making arrangements to consult them, please visit www.nyhistory.org/library/visit.
Records related to almoners and to members are restricted from access for 35 years; that restriction is noted within the finding aid at the relevant series or subseries level.
Preferred Citation Note
This collection should be cited as The Saint Andrew's Society of the State of New York Records, MS 2997, The New-York Historical Society.
Related Materials Note
The Printed Collections of the New-York Historical Society hold a collection of material related to Saint Andrew's Society of the State of New York under the call number F128 HS2725 .S14.
There is also a small amount of oversize archival material, separate from this collection, at the New-York Historical Society labeled: Y-Saint Andrew's Society.
Processing Information
The collection was processed by Luis Rodriguez in 2017-2018. The finding aid was updated in July 2022 to reflect amended restrictions agreed between the donor and N-YHS.
Account books. Ephemera. Letters (correspondence) Photographs. Records (documents). Registers (lists) Charities -- New York (State) -- New York. Clubs -- New York (State) -- New York. Scottish Americans -- New York (State) New York (State) -- Social life and customs. Saint Andrew's Society of the State of New York -- Archives.
Series I: Administrative Records1785-2008
Scope and Contents Note
This series contains material related to the operations and management of the Society as a whole. It is arranged into subseries that detail the organization's institutional structure, which includes an early treasurer's book, minutes, reports, printed histories, committee records, and office files.Subseries I.1: Treasurer's Book1785-18601
Scope and Contents Note
The treasurer's book is a manuscript general ledger documenting the society's income and expenses from 1785 to 1860. Treasurer's records for the period after 1860 exist within the subseries Minutes and Annual Reports.Treasurer's Book1785 - 18601Subseries I.2: Minutes1835-1990
Scope and Contents
Minutes (1835 - 1989) provide an account of the Society's activities and include information related to charitable giving, membership, constitutional changes, and other facets of the organization's operation. Bound minutes are in some cases supplemented, or in later years, replaced by foldered material that includes correspondence, agendas, copies of reports, and the minutes themselves.
General Meeting minutes (1835- 1990) record the larger meetings called by the President to elect officers, receive annual reports, form committees, and otherwise express the intentions of the Society as a whole. These include Annual, Semi-Annual, Preparatory, and various Special Meetings. Bound minutes exist from 1835 to 1960. Foldered material runs from 1950 to 1990.
Minutes of the Board of Managers (1884 - 1989) record monthly meetings that address changes in membership, review monthly financial and charity reports, and attend to other business as needed. Bound volumes cover the period from 1884 to 1966. Foldered material exists from 1953 to 1989.
Some of what is contained in General Meeting minutes in relation to reports and officers can also be found in the subseries Annual Reports. Likewise, information related to the membership of individuals in the Society can also be found in the series Membership.
Arrangement Note
General Meeting minutes are arranged first, followed by Board of Managers' Meeting minutes. Each set of minutes is ordered chronologically.General Meetings1835 September 16 - 1866 November 302General Meetings1867 August 8 - 1893 November 93General Meetings1893 December 1 - 1899 May 44General Meetings1895 March 5 - Scope and Contents
Annual reports published by the Saint Andrew's Society of the State of New York contain summaries of activity which may include: lists of officers and committees; financial statements; reports from Secretaries, Almoners, various committees, and other officers; lists of active members; "in memoriam" notices; and the organization's constitution.
Annual reports from the years 1873 to 1976 are bound in hardcover volumes. Duplicate paperback volumes are housed separately. Scope and Contents Note
Brief printed notices contain lists of officers, reports of the Secretary, meeting schedules, statements regarding dues, and other announcements. Scope and Contents Note
The Society periodically produced publications, in addition to the annual reports, that compiled various types of organizational information. These items include governing rules and narrative histories that describe the leadership and activities of the organization over time. Scope and Contents Note
Governance Committee Records primarily document the process of selecting members to lead and administer the work of the organization. The Nominating Committee selected officers, chaplains, physicians, and members of the Banquet Committee. The Standing Committee appointed a Finance Committee and attended to other executive business. The subseries contains correspondence, meeting minutes, lists of candidates, and related material.
Arrangement Note
Nominating Committee records are arranged first, followed by the records of the Standing Committee. Scope and Contents Note
Charitable records document the Society's mission to provide aid to individuals of Scottish descent. Responsibility for the dispersal of aid originally fell to the Board of Managers, until 1841, when the Society hired an Almoner to investigate cases and provide aid. In addition to the primary fund, special funds were also established for specific charitable purposes, which can be seen in the President's Fund and Scholarship Fund subseries.Subseries II.1: Manager's and Almoner's Record Books1802-1979
Scope and Contents Note
The subseries contains ledger volumes that detail individual requests for aid and corresponding disbursements made by the Society. The volumes are in chronological order.
Conditions Governing Access
By agreement with the donor of the collection, almoners' records are restricted from access for 35 years from the date of the record. Accordingly, as of 2022, all almoners' records from 1987 and later are restricted from access.Manager's Book1802 - 182561Manager's Book 1825 - 184662Account of Burials and Record of Hospital Cases1890 - 197863Almoner's Record BookNovember 1905 - September 190764Almoner's Record BookOctober 1907 - April 190965Almoner's Record BookMay 1909 - July 191166Almoner's Record BookDecember 1918 - January 192267Almoner's Record BookFebruary 1922 - September 192468Almoner's Record BookSeptember 1924 - February 192769Almoner's Record BookFebruary 1927 - August 192870Almoner's Record BookSeptember 1928 - July 193071Almoner's Record BookAugust 1930 - October 193372Almoner's Record BookNovember 1933 - April 193873Almoner's Record BookMay 1938 - January 194574Almoner's Record BookFebruary 1945 - September 195375Almoner's Record BookOctober 1953 - January 196276Almoner's Record BookFebruary 1962 - June 197377Almoner's Record BookJuly 1973 - May 197978Subseries II.2: Almoner's Reports1916-1980

The subseries contains files kept by the Almoner related to individual applicants and recipients of aid. Material includes correspondence, applications, and related documentation. The files are arranged alphabetically according the the applicant's name.

Scope and Contents Note
The President's Fund was established in 1944 in response to the effects of World War II in Scotland. Separate from the Permanent Fund, which could only be spent in New York, it allowed the Society to supply aid to Scottish charities at the discretion of the President. Records in this subseries consist chiefly of correspondence related to individual donors and recipient organizations. There are also administrative reports on the status of the fund.Correspondence and reports1944 - 1947281Correspondence and reports1948 - 1950282Correspondence and reports1951 - 1954283Correspondence and reports1955 - 1956284Correspondence and reports1957 - 1958285Correspondence and reports1959 - 1960286Correspondence and reports1961287Correspondence and reports1962288Correspondence and reports1963289Correspondence and reports1964291Correspondence and reports1965; 1969 - 1976292Correspondence and reports1982 - 1983293Correspondence and reports1984 - 1985294Correspondence and reports1986 - 1989295Subseries II.5: Scholarship Fund1955-1992
Scope and Contents Note
The Scholarship Fund (1955 – 1992) was established as part of the Society's Bicentennial celebrations. For the majority of its history, it provided financial aid to Scottish students wishing to study in American universities and vice versa.
Arrangement Note
Material in this subseries was filed in two categories prior to processing. The first was a general file containing administrative correspondence, fundraising material, program information, and other records. The second contained correspondence and records related to the individual scholarship recipients. This arrangement is preserved under the headings "Committee records", which is arranged first, and "Student files", which follows. There is, however, some overlap between the two categories. Each set is ordered chronologically.Committee records1955 - 1959296Committee records1960297Committee records1961 - 1962298Committee records, fundraising luncheon1962301Committee records1963 - 1969302Committee records1979 - 1982303Committee records1983 - 1984304Committee records, student reports1983 - 1989305Committee records1985 - 1987306Committee records 1988 - 1989307Committee records1992308Student files1960 - 1964311Student files1964 - 1966312Student files1965 - 1968313Student files1968 - 1971314Student files1971 - 1975315Student files1975 - 1978316Student files1978 - 1980317Student files1980 - 1981318Student files1981 - 1982319Student files1982 - 1983321Student files1983 - 1984322Student files, American1984 - 1985323Student files, Scottish1984 - 1985324Student files, American1985 - 1986325Student files, Scottish1985 - 1986326Student files, American1986 - 1987327Student files, Scottish1986 - 1987331Student files, American1987 - 1988332Student files, Scottish1987 - 1988333Student files, American1988 - 1989334Student files, Scottish1988 - 1989335Series III: Membership Records (RESTRICTIONS APPLY)circa 1820-2000s
Scope and Contents Note
Membership records contain information about the individuals who have belonged to the Saint Andrew's Society of the State of New York.
Arrangement Note
The series consists of the following subseries: Registers, Member Applications, "Archived" Member Files spanning the period from the 1850s to the 2000s, and "Unarchived" Member Files, spanning the period from the 1850s to the 1980s. The archived and unarchived member files reflect the arrangement of the material at the time of accession. Archived files are foldered, and unarchived files are housed in original envelopes.
Conditions Governing Access
By agreement with the donor of the collection, member records are restricted from access for 35 years from the date of the record. Accordingly, as of 2022, all member records from 1987 and later are restricted from access.Subseries III.1: Registerscirca 1820-1987
Arrangement Note
Bound volumes are arranged first, followed by foldered material. Within the bound volumes, manuscript material is first, followed by typescripts, and then printed matter. Apart from those considerations, items are ordered chronologically according to their date of creation.
Scope and Contents Note
The subseries contains historical lists of members compiled mostly during the early 20th century.List of members, 1785 - 1820undated, circa 182079Roll of members, volume 1, 1756 - 1906190680Roll of members, volume 2, 1906 - 1960circa 1906 - 196081Roll of members, volume 3, 1960 - 1987circa 1960 - 198782Typescript roll of members from 1756 to 1910 undated, circa 191083Typescript biographical register, volume 2, part 1, 1807 - 1831circa 1920s84Typescript biographical register, volume 2, part 2, 1832 - 1856circa 1920s85Typescript biographical register, 1857 - 1906, volume 1circa 1920 - 193086Typescript biographical register, 1857 - 1906, volume 2circa 1920 - 193087Typescript biographical register, 1857 - 1906, volume 3circa 1920 - 193088Typescript register, 1907 - 1919circa 1920 - 193089Roster of Saint Andrew's Society of the State of New York with Biographical . Scope and Contents Note
Member applications contain information about individuals wishing to join the Society. Volumes are arranged chronologically. Within the volumes, however, the applications are organized alphabetically by name. See also the subseries Member Files, which contains unbound applications.Propositions for Membership1878 - 189794Propositions for Membership1895 - 189795Proposals for Membership. Scope and Contents Note
Member Files contain application materials and correspondence related to an individual's involvement in the Society. All refer to inactive members. "Archived" Member Files reflect the filing system from about the 1990s to the time of accession. They therefore include the files of members active in the 1990s and 2000s. Additionally, many earlier member files, primarily although not exclusively those with last names beginning with 'A' through 'C', had been interfiled into this subseries. Scope and Contents Note
Member Files contain application materials and correspondence related to an individual's involvement in the Society. All refer to inactive members. "Unarchived" Member Files reflect the filing system from about the 1850s to the 1980s, and the files remain housed in their original envelopes. Scope and Contents Note
Records of events held by the Society contain ephemera and transcripts from Anniversary Banquets, memos and correspondence involved in the planning of various events, and photographs of the events themselves.Subseries IV.1: Anniversary Banquet Proceedings1893-1989115
Scope and Contents Note
This subseries contains ephemera and transcriptions of the proceedings at the Society's Anniversary Banquets. Included are menus, programs that detail guests and seating arrangements, and in some cases, the text of speeches given on the occasion. Bound volumes are arranged first, followed by foldered material. Scope and Contents Note
This subseries contains photographs documenting the social and cultural events held by the society. The majority are focused on Anniversary Banquets and gatherings related to Tartan Week.
Arrangement Note
The photographs are arranged in rough chronological order. Loose photographs and photograph albums are housed together.Event photographscirca 1950 - 196980-81Event photographs1979 - 198982Event photographs1990 - 199483Event photographs1995 - 199984Event photographs2000 - 200485Event photographs2005 - 200686Event photographs2007 - 200887Event photographs2009 - 201288Event photographs 2013 - 2014, undated 89Oversize photographs1935 - 1950100SASNY OS 1Oversize photographs1950 - 1965100SASNY OS 2Series V: The Pibroch1944-1994
Scope and Contents Note
The Pibroch was the newsletter published by the Saint Andrew's Society of the State of New York from 1944 to 1994. It featured reviews of meetings, member news, reports from officers, pieces of cultural and historical interest, and information related to social events.
The series is divided into two subseries. The first subseries consists of the published issues of the Pibroch. The second subseries, publication records, contains files held by the editor of the Pibroch. The Recording Secretary was typically responsible for editing the newsletter, and the files include mockups, page proofs, clippings, copyright forms, and correspondence. Material is arranged chronologically within each subseries. Scope and Contents Note
Miscellaneous Historical Material contains items of historical value informally collected by the Society. While direct historical documentation such as constitutions or printed histories is contained primarily in the Administrative Records series, this series gathers material such as clippings, reproductions, photographs, and printed matter that complements material found elsewhere in the collection.Subseries VI.1: Related Organizations1744-1981
Scope and Contents Note
Material from Saint Andrew's Societies based in other locations contexualizes the work of the Saint Andrew's Society in New York.
